org.tantalum.jme

Class TantalumMIDlet

  • java.lang.Object
    • javax.microedition.midlet.MIDlet
      • org.tantalum.jme.TantalumMIDlet

  • public abstract class TantalumMIDlet
extends javax.microedition.midlet.MIDlet
    This is a convenience class to embody the best practice patterns for starting and stopping an app which uses Tantalum. Using this class is optional, but makes your life simpler. You can either extend it, or implement your own variant.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected static int DEFAULT_NUMBER_OF_WORKER_THREADS
      A suggested number of background Worker threads for this platform.

      protected TantalumMIDlet(int numberOfWorkerThreads, boolean routeDebugOutputToUsbSerialPort)
      If you create a MIDlet constructor, you must call super() as the first line of your MIDlet's constructor.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_NUMBER_OF_WORKER_THREADS

        protected static final int DEFAULT_NUMBER_OF_WORKER_THREADS
        A suggested number of background Worker threads for this platform. Use this if you do not have a specific reason to increase or decrease it. More threads means more concurrent operations such as HTTP GET, but can increase context switching overhead and contention for scarce bandwidth under poor network conditions. More threads is more useful on multi-core hardware. Series40 phones have one core, but fairly low context switching overhead so concurrency works well. If you find foreground tasks bogging down or too much network contention when there are parallel HTTP GET operations, try reducing the number of threads to 2.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TantalumMIDlet

        Create a MIDlet that hooks into the MIDlet life-cycle events to start and stop the background Worker threads with proper notification.
        Parameters:

      • TantalumMIDlet

        protected TantalumMIDlet(int numberOfWorkerThreads,
              boolean routeDebugOutputToUsbSerialPort)
        If you create a MIDlet constructor, you must call super() as the first line of your MIDlet's constructor. Alternatively, you can call Worker.init() yourself with custom parameters for special needs.
        Parameters:
        numberOfWorkerThreads - - - Feel free to use TantalumMIDlet.DEFAULT_NUMBER_OF_WORKER_THREADS
        routeDebugOutputToUsbSerialPort -

    • Method Detail

      • destroyApp

        protected void destroyApp(boolean unconditional)
        Do not call this directly. Call exitMidlet(false) instead. This is part of MIDlet lifecycle model and may be called by the platform, for example when a users presses and holds the RED button on their phone to force an application to close.
        Specified by:
        destroyApp in class javax.microedition.midlet.MIDlet
        Parameters:
        unconditional -
